UmsSBSKiANXOYPXcOLKsEQ.text: Found this pace by accident, but what a find! Family owned and operated for 40+ years. Grandfather was running the kitchen, Son was greeting and taking orders and youngsters were there eating. Food was just fabulous. Spinach and ricotta tortellini was divine. Dining partners had the spaghetti with prawn and chilli, they loved it. Service was friendly not posh. We were in a time constraint due to going to the theatre. My next visit will be longer to enjoy all the courses. ( they have a 2 course pre-theatre prix fixe for £17.50). Highly recommended.

06Je0Cd7zaFbWl6hypWP7A.text: A very good family Italian restaurant. Has probably been there for ever and does rather look it (nothing glam in the decor but not shabby) but first rate food.

3fjQYAn9MWuWglmlizslXw.text: Excellent food! Very tasty! Good service! Recommend!

0y8fmzAEbBKL18zJS4V34g.text: Bad lighting, cheapish chairs, white tablecloths and lots of peach dominate the scene - with some flowers and a very practical looking bar thrown in for good measure.  But no, this is not a wedding reception.  This is Vasco & Piero's Pavilion Restaurant (announced loudly, with a flourish, as you would expect Paul, the big, heavy-moustached Italian son of Vasco to do... but he doesn't, he just works the front room - Vasco is in the kitchen, and sadly, Piero is now gone), and this is a special place.  For one, it's an old-school, family-run Italian place which is an interesting thing to find on this corner in Soho, just off Oxford Street.  For two, the service is kind and the food is excellent.The Italian menu - with an Umbrian leaning - changes twice daily.  This is refreshing, but I've only been able to get my star dish, grilled calf's liver with cabbage, a couple of times.  On the other had, when I finally got up the nerve to order off-menu (after becoming loyally familiar to their menu, I started to figure out what they consistently kept in the kitchen), they gave me a knowing eye and brought me an even better version.  This made me very happy. It is not without its faults (see, i.e., interior design above), but after their bread basket improved immensely of late, Vasco & Piero's has just moved up to my number 2 favourite Italian restaurant in London.

OT7-mpgrJjS0Gmlc65sHww.text: Like many people ( I guess) I came here after a few cocktails hoping to finish the evening with a nice meal.  Was my destination so wandered around soho a little til I found it.  Simple white table cloth restaurant.  Food was good.  Simple pastas were perfectly cooked a very tatsty.  Would definitely go again.

LpR5su6yqm29DT515drrcg.text: The best Italian around. I keep coming back over and over again whenever I'm back in London. Kind and lively staff, and extraordinary dishes.

ewe5nZjgTyJ_gSkc59IzEg.text: Vasco & Piero's Pavilion has been there for 40 odd years, anonymously squatting on the unlovely Poland Street. Synonymous with London's media scene, it's one of those places that advertising execs used to take folk for a roister-doister, "it's alright, we're not needed back at the office anytime soon, now how about that contract" lunch into afternoon into evening event to celebrate. And in all the times I've been in there, in that state, I've never remembered to ask about the name though...The menu downstairs is set, something I'd be less bothered about if there were more than eight of us. Especially having drooled over the menu upstairs, with its extensive list of pastas and wonderful sounding dishes; lombetto, a cured loin of Umbrian pork, tortellioni of duck or seabass, fennel flavoured salamis, the list goes on...Not having been there for a few years, I was looking forward to this. God knows why, but I went for a standard but unadventurous asparagus and mozzarella starter. Nothing special. It came drizzled with a beautifully fresh, zingy and fragrant basil oil but the trimmed asparagus felt like it hadn't been out of the fridge for long enough. I suppose it's partly my fault for ordering it way out of season. If the starter was a bit of a let down, then the pasta course reminded me why I love good Italian food. Little pockets of silky smooth aubergine ravioli came with tooth sticking aubergine skin fried into tiny tasty splinters scattered atop the sun yellow pasta parcels. The room silenced until the pasta had vanished. The main of duck breast was served simply with green beans, great quality ingredients and lovely with a lipsmacking jus. A simple desert of baked ricotta was slightly spoilt by too sharp raspberries, but was in itself lovely. Like Andrew Edmunds, The Ivy and a number of other little Soho gems, it hasn't changed much in years, and keeps going in such a cutthroat location because it gets the fundamentals right time after time. The chefs inspiration, and many of the ingredients, come from Umbria in central Italy. They cater to a local crowd who know the staff and each other and take the odd party, like us, and shoehorn them away in a downstairs room where they won't disturb the regulars. Not that I minded, it was perfectly pleasant, if a little like dining in a provincial hotel with it's light and forgettable decor. On thing to note about the upstairs is that the noise levels frequently get high. It's not somewhere for a quiet tete a tete (but ideal to tell someone some bad news..)

photos.caption: Photo of Vasco & Piero's Pavilion Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Vasco & Piero's Pavilion Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

xFyHG9jEbTmh7xLijl3SpA.text: Came in with 2 kids who were 10 and 7 and were treated great.  The yellowfin tuna was amazing that both my wife and myself had.  My kids stole some from us.  My 6 yo just does simple pasta which they were happy to accommodate.   Compared to all the places that have poor service around here this place was the opposite.

ajiQTJP6oC-XjhzVkvJWmQ.text: Normally when the wines are not so good- i can not give 5 stars- BUT- the food here is so GREAT! I was really impressed on how simple yet tasty the food was. What a great find! The service was fantastic as well. Thank you YELPERS for leading me to this italian gem! I will be back!

4YDi1jSAtG6tTapbcrROjQ.text: This place was excellent!I got to have the fun experience here of introducing a friend to his first burrata. Yes, this cheese is amazing, and they have a pretty darn good one here at this place. If you haven't had this delicious cheese, dripping in olive oil, perhaps you have not lived, and perhaps you should fix that ASAP.The rest of the food was very respectable. But it was the burrata that made a second appearance at the dessert course -- and the only somewhat amused staff were happy to indulge us.Gluten-free notes: Not only are many of the dishes naturally gluten-free, but they also have gluten-free pasta! They can tell you what sauces you can have and were flexible about making me a pasta I was excited to eat.

8Xe1BfUHpYSQaUwgraEuQQ.text: This place was excellent in every respect.The ambience is charming and comfortable, the food is traditional, but imaginative in presentation and extremely fresh and delicious. I came here with a party of five. Made a reservation online, but when we got here they asked us to wait 20 minutes. We were put off for a moment, but they took our coats and brought us prosecco while we were waiting. While we waited we got to take in the scene and talk to one of the owners. The proprietors are a father and son from Umbria, been in business for 40+ years. Most of the staff is from Italy. You certainly can taste that in the food! I'll definitely be back for more. My chicken was incredible. The beets with ginger were a delightful twist. I ate every bite on my plate, and I'm usually a half eater! Everyone in my party was very happy with their pasta dishes and salads as well. The staff were all very friendly and sweet with our 8 year old.

HmfE7pwLIsPDYRhJIMScwg.text: I'm really just writing this to offer yet another, hopefully convincing, opinion that this restaurant is excellent and a place to go if you want to have a good meal in Soho that is relaxed, with high-quality food and wine, attentive but unfussy service and a total lack of pretentiousness, though you will need to bring your good table manners as staff and customers here know how to dine properly.  I took a date there, but it's probably more a place to take a good friend/s, your partner, or close family members.  It's more homely and comfortable than romantic.There is an incredible menu, in that it changes constantly because it offers good, seasonal ingredients they can get their hands on that day.  I ate chicken livers, ham and mushrooms on crostini for a starter, then guinea fowl tortelloni with black Umbrian truffles and sage butter.  My dining partner had some kind of stuffed pork dish that I can't remember much about, as it wasn't on my plate and I was preoccupied with my own food, but I was told it was excellent and there wasn't a scrap left at the end of dinner, so I didn't get to taste it :-(.I tend not to rate anything perfectly unless I'm drunk or experienced some kind of religious moment whilst partaking.  The Pavilion deserves something closer to 4.5 stars.  They could use a better bread basket at the start of the meal, the crostino was a little soggy and the decor is tired.   But overall, it's a little gem with fantastic food I've discovered in Soho that I'll be returning to.  Next time, I intend to save room for dessert.

vUkApjLWYH3Zdn89a_k79w.text: This place is excellent - fresh, delicate, perfectly prepared and presented food.  In an area where there are so many pre-theatre menus and 'deals' that are just plain mediocre Vascco and Piero's is just plain wonderful.  I just booked my third pre-opera meal here.  Consistency, knowing that you will get a great meal every time is unusual but very usual here.

ZgZ2ikaRo6CY8SpWJ19PlQ.text: A recent Yelp convert, I had high expectations when I was looking for an Italian restaurant around Carnaby St. Up came this one, only three ratings (all good) and some amusing comments. As soon as we got there, we knew we were in for a treat. Yes, the decor is a little bit wanting, but perhaps you could put it down to rustic charm! The wine list was extensive and had a few favourites, and as is the norm for me, I went for a lovely Chianti. There was a wonderful menu and I was thoroughly pleased by the two courses that I had (and the nibbles they brought out beforehand). I probably didn't need to finish off the night with some grappa but I guess one must!The staff were wonderful and friendly and we had a good chat with them as the night finished. Top establishment!

8D5cypnRAE8UOXy2qmpH5w.text: We actually ended up here by accident one night, but they were able to get us in without a reservation (they were very busy) and I'm really glad they did!  It's a smallish space, but did not feel crowded.  It did get a little loud when the place was packed though but I think that would only bother you if you really need quiet while you're dining.The service was very nice, and the owner came out and chatted with us and everyone there.  The use only fresh ingredients and change their menu regularly.  One person in our group is allergic to gluten, but they had many options on their menu that worked for her, and they even had a gluten free pasta that they made specially for her.This place was a great find in a great location, and I highly recommend it if you're in the mood for some good Italian!

H2SL9kbnVjS0iDT9lQnYoA.text: This place was a wonderful find in London. Found it using Yelp reviews and we all loved it and considered eating there twice on our visit. We plan to go back again next trip to London!

qUmletALA8xG-Unv1WmyuQ.text: All the other reviews are correct .  Walked 1+ miles and it was worth it. Finish with the tiramisu!

AenEvNWfn-ymKKiWpzNhhg.text: Vasco was the venue of our office Christmas dinner last week. After a vigorous internal discussion, we decided on coming here ... and in hindsight, it was a very good choice :)Its located right at the heart of Soho, on Poland Street. The menu is not typical of the Italian restaurant chains that all of us are familiar with. The menu didn't have any pizza, or risotto ... and only 4-5 pastas. But the other, relatively unfamiliar (to me) dishes were great in their own right.I ordered a lamb starter. It was cooked rare ... pink in colour, along with some kind of leaves. Now my distaste for greens is legendary ... but the dish was prepared well enough for me to ignore it. That was a big plus.For the main course i had a preparation of grilled duck with beans. I had asked for the duck to be prepared well done, which probably contributed to the long wait for the item. It was cooked perfectly ... not oily at all. The dish was very enjoyable. A colleague of mine sitting close by had ordered spaghetti with prawns. It was fabulous, but i liked my order better. I also tried a few of the lighter dishes on the table ... baked potatoes for one ... and all of them exceeded expectations.All the food was inter-spaced by copious amounts of different varieties of red wine. I am not a wine connoisseur, so all i can say is that they were good.I became a tad adventurous when the time came for ordering dessert. I went for some grappa ... for only the 3rd time in my life. Admittedly this one was smoother than the ones i had had before, but looking back, i should still have stuck to the ice-cream.The service can do with a bit of improvement. One of our servers admitted to not knowing English at all. I failed to understand why he was in a customer-facing role then.I am not sure of the cost, but from what i remember from the menu, it wasn't cheap, but the prices weren't outrageous either. I will certainly try Vasco out again :)

5M-bcUORSAVi3VLLUrtKyA.text: I've never eaten here, but I wanted to publicly commend the employees of Vasco & Piero's Pavilion (particularly Paul, who I believe is the owner or manager) for really helping me out today.I had a bit of a missing persons case for the last few days when a friend of mine went MIA, stopped going in to work, and no one had heard from her in a few days. I knew she had a business lunch the other day at Vasco & Piero's, so two of us went over to the restaurant on our lunch break with a photo to ask if she'd arrived for her reservation. Paul checked with all of his employees, and got my phone number with the promise to call if he heard anything. I got three phone calls from him over the course of the afternoon, offering to check the credit card receipts to see if her card had been used there, and giving me news that he'd checked in with additional employees as they'd arrived for the evening shift.My friend, it turns out, was bedridden with a nasty cold and had her phone turned off, so everything was fine. Paul, though, had gotten personally concerned for her welfare and really went out of his way to help in any way he could. Though I can't opine on the quality of the food, the quality of the staff and management is some of the best I've ever encountered, and I wish the best for Paul and his kind and helpful team.

f4OCrIaMGrpebIsm5GaRCQ.text: very good food, wine selection was excellent.  Authentic Italian, reminded us of last year's trip to Italy.  Only problem was it is in Soho, and right next to several loud drunken pubs/bars, so the location and atmosphere suffer a little bit late at night, when we went.  Otherwise a superb meal.

Lt-Vmgcy_n3Cgrue49DGKQ.text: Wow! This is among the most amazing Italian food I have ever experienced, very attentive waitstaff as well. The desserts were also wonderful. I had the most smooth grappa of my life here, wish I got the name. They were helpful to our vegetarian needs as well.

FBTNSmMUrLN4Jjc_HuJqag.text: By far our best meal in London! I wish we would have found this restaurant before our last night, as we would have dined a few more times.  Exceptional in food and service. Our waiter was perfect.  My wife is Italian and very particular about Italian food.  You will not be disappointed!!

lLlBxZZVPuqaBP7FmyDE3g.text: I should probably point out, before I actually get into this review, that Vasco is a friend of the family. Heaven forfend that I should show favouritism to someone simply because I know them - I once broke both of my brother's kneecaps to make sure I got the last glug from a particularly good bottle of Pinot Noir - but I'm an honest sort. You guys should have all the available info to make your choice. I tend to go there for occasions with my family, so I associate it with a sort of slightly genteel drunkenness. It had been a while, but we popped along last Friday, and all the memories of brilliant, authentic Italian cooking came flooding back. Vasco sources most of his ingredients from his homeland. That means olive oil and prosciutto from Umbria, the best pecorino cheese and, when the season's on, the pick of Piedmont's truffles. He makes his own pasta, which is wonderfully light and enwraps some gorgeous concoctions of meat, veg, cheese and the like. Heston-style complications these are not: each dish is minimal, with perhaps 3 or 4 ingredients to it. The flavours speak for themselves. Try hand-made duck tortelloni with rosemary, or gnocchi with crispy calamari, or the heaven-sent strips of calves' liver with onions and spinach. In between, if you're lucky, you might be sent a little tiger prawn, butterflied and grilled with a little lemon and olive oil. Or a single raviolo, stuffed with heaven knows what. If you have room for dessert, you're a better diner than I. I love Vasco's. Great occasion. Lovely man. Food's brilliant. It's not cheap, but food like this shouldn't be. Still, it's not wallet-bustingly expensive. One star removed only because it's in bloody Soho. Tch.

6mBnH9hmZfuAxRgeRb3HyA.text: Best bruschetta I've ever had!  Service was warm and personable; entrees were elegantly platted and tasted divine.  Early dinner is highly discounted.

g9Qsoa-XW5AXMCFa4akusQ.text: Fantastic ambience, food, location and service. I will make this a regular. The only thing i might suggest is a little background music instead of silence and maybe put a bit more space between the tables. The bartender was great and made a terrific cappuccino. Very attentive servers.

r1E_ycCEB_N7sMKWwKRtwQ.text: Delicious food! Staff is very courteous and helpful. I've asked for a suggestion of wine explaining what kind of wine I normally enjoy. They got one sooo good. Highly recommend!The ambience is not too noisy though the tables are pretty close to each other. They have a few options for vegetarian. You won't be disappointed. I've had the vegetable soup (it was delicious) and the spinach tortellini, I really recommend it. Sorry but Didn't take pictures...it was too good to stop and take a picture

tVnMGLnWIIeP0xBI4u23PQ.text: Nice Italian restaurant and great experience in Soho. The waiter and chef are really friendly and gave us samples on the food we never tried before. We ordered the grilled tuna and bolognese. The strawberry brûlée( forgot what it is called on the menu) is so cute, and tastes good. Overall really nice experience! Worth visiting!

photos.caption: Photo of Vasco & Piero's Pavilion Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Tuna
Photo of Vasco & Piero's Pavilion Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Brulee

JA_NrGPd_TlWb7AlgUskkw.text: I had my birthday dinner here, and everything worked great. We were a large group of fourteen people, so were allocated the private space downstairs. Ambience was just appropriately intimate and Italian, and the service was great. I particularly liked our waiter. He really went the extra mile to help split our bills and ensure everything ran smoothly. Food was also excellent. I ordered the ham and melon for starter, then prawn pasta for main. Both dishes were solid -- in particular, the ham and prawns were very fresh. I wish they had a nicer presentation, but I guess their aim was perhaps to make the dishes feel homemade-like. A few of my friends with Italian roots said they liked the food too. Definitely would recommend the place -- solid food and service for very reasonable prices!

ftPAzhd8dtgoLPS-4nPsTA.text: I searched London in my first year here for a truly exceptional Italian meal. One would think with the proximity to Italy, this might be easy: it is not. There options, but one has to search.Thankfully, I found Vasco and Piero's. The fare here is old-world comfort food set in romantic, but relatively subtle interior. The sauces are rich, the spaghetti is cooked to al dente perfection, and the desserts...now I'm salivating. There's a quality wine menu. Not the best, but plenty of options. Some of the waiters are a bit terse, but most engender that boisterous spirit many of us have some to equate with Italians. For example: when - on arriving - I once asked how fast we could finish our lunch, the waiter handed me a piece of paper. "Your check," he said. That kept us laughing through the entire meal.Anyway, Vasco & Piero's is a gem. I will keep coming back here for my carbofix as much as possible.

jiQhy7pwWtArpgHT3dtZ6Q.text: Went here based on a recommendation. Excellent food in London, a city where really good food is hard to come by. Very authentic Italian and decent prices. Just very tight quarters.

Bi9EQXar_JA69pLVespW0Q.text: Fresh and hearty Italian food. Very nice and cozy inside, staff were excellent. Had the Creme Caramel for dessert, it was great.

vKsL5NyN7LZvtHpHc7MHmQ.text: Great attentive service. We ordered burrata and carpaccio pear w/pecorino. Both were very tasty. Great wine list of wonderful italian wines. The staff speaks italian which always says to me that this place is legit. We ordered the orchiette w/sausage and broccoli and the spaghettini w/shrimp. I wish we weren't so stuffed and would have loved to have dessert.

photos.caption: Photo of Vasco & Piero's Pavilion Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Spaghettini with shrimp

EnbPaYwv15xg4UiTLDx1pg.text: Tried the sword fish and it was good. Table raved about their other fished, which they dissected off the bone - the weren't leaving an ounce behind. The staff was so nice. We filled up on bread though. The  wine was delish as well. The staff threw in a small complimentary salad (?) to nosh on.  This was the Italian meal of the week.

vQTbIce5ZCq8KdnwG120Bg.text: Service was awkward when I first walked in.  There were a few staff standing there, but all ignored me after turning to face me.  What the heck.  The interaction between staff and the table was continued its awkwardness throughout the meal, which itself wasn't too bad. I'd perhaps return for the food, but not necessarily for the service that other reviewers seemed to have gotten.

AayUk5w6xNn8TG1BUnIJtQ.text: Excellent fish and pasta in this unassuming white tablecloth spot.Food: 4, Service: 3, Atmosphere: 3Cost to worth it rating: 4 (expected it to be higher so was pleasantly surprised)Return worthiness: sureHighlights:- Fish: I had the sea bass and my co-diner had the cod and both were cooked well and tasted great. Mine came with a bit of tomato sauce and his arribiatta loved the freshness of the tomato.- Minestrone soup: huge bowl of broth filled to the brim with vegetables. I needed to eat something relatively healthy and it was cold outside, so it hit the spot - Pasta: after eying another table's meal we got a small portion to share and it was quite good: linguine pasta seemed fresh and sauce was light and delicious.- Wine: they had 2 sizes of glasses and a pretty good selection. We got 2 Italian reds and both were goodLowlights:- Empty when other spots had long waits, so we were a bit worried but it was fine.Had a nice meal and could see myself ducking in here again for a meal.

ZqZtdU5Z8KvnjY6hUIcG6w.text: The service was ok, but the manager or owner wasn't friendly at all. The food was also just ok. I had the pear carpaccio starter, but the pears were very over-ripe and were basically mush on the plate. If you want Italian, I'd try for somewhere else.

Y_ECPO3YFJ5YEpKmRoGrug.text: Really nicely decorated good service had a few rounds of cocktails really tasty would recommend my favourite was the expresso cocktail

photos.caption: Photo of Vasco & Piero's Pavilion Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Vasco & Piero's Pavilion Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Vasco & Piero's Pavilion Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

wyPROxvPhlOfaGGkDn63rg.text: Excellent Italian food at a reasonable cost in a small restaurant in Soho. I started with a roasted beet salad which was mixed with cherry tomatoes and avocado which was both visually colorful and very tasty. The whole table tried some and enjoyed. For my main course I ordered the tagliatelle ragu. The pasta was cooked to perfection with the ragu adding a perfect salty component to the dish. I also tried some of the orecchiette which was also very good. To finish it off I had the panna cotta but the waiter mistakenly delivered the panettone. He left the panettone for us to eat as the kitchen corrected the mistake and it was the winner of the four desserts we tried, though each of the others were very good. Wait staff was very friendly and accommodating, A+ dining experience and all for about 50 pounds per person including a bottle of wine!

ttEu3seg4ZIUQ2VB8c3PZA.text: Vasco & Piero's Pavilion is a gem in the heart of Soho. Great atmosphere and very tasty food, definitely one of my favourite Italian restaurants in London.In early 2014, I stumbled into Vasco & Piero's Pavilion in Soho. I found an absolutely lovely place that can be easily overlooked. I really liked the friendly staff and also the classy atmosphere of this restaurant with a lot of light and beautiful paintings on the wall that do not distract you from the stunning food. It simply was a joy to eat there.I started with a rosé wine, something I do not drink too often, but this one was delicious and very crisp and fresh.For dinner, I ordered the very tasty home-made tagliatelle with beef ragout. Rich in flavour and an all-around enjoyable dish.The panna cotta with strawberries and, I think, caramel sauce was light and refreshing after the hearty main.I rounded off my visit with an espresso. Typical for an Italian restaurant, they serve a strong, bitter coffee. Not really the kind of coffee I prefer, but as I knew what to expect and because it all worked for me after the sweet dessert, I did not mind it.Without any doubt, Vasco & Piero's Pavilion in Soho is worth a visit. It is such a lovely restaurant - for sure I will be back for another meal soon.

rsjEXjI9F6m9BQHncGmozA.text: Came here last Thursday night for dinner. I arrived early to an unsurprisingly empty restaurant but the place what's heaving when I left.I did not think it very prepossessing, tucked away on a corner and easy to miss, particularly with scaffolding outside currently. It's small and quite unremarkable inside with simple white tablecloths and decor. Despite this there is a great ambiance and the staff who are friendly and attentive do their best to put you at your ease immediately.I had a very mediocre G&T before embarking on the wine. Don't bother coming here for cocktails. If that's your thing you need to go elsewhere. The wine however was quite good. We were recommended a £40-odd from the menu whose name I do not recall but the server said it was from the vineyard of a friend of his who made his fortune in shampoo. It was very drinkable but not the best.You come here for the food. I started with the pink beef carpaccio which was absolutely delicious. My companion had the burrata and that was a bit disappointing. I've had better from Waitrose. Then I had the grilled calamari salad which was gorgeous. The spaghettini was fine. To finish we had a cheese selection which was perfect.Good atmosphere and great service.I would come back again and try lunchtime as the menu is changed twice daily.

83LyVXatVPaplezKdjQUkQ.text: Well then, five stars says it all. I had the handmade mushroom pasta. It was good and you will like it. Portions are perfect, any larger and the quality would suffer.

nr2lhQVtzJtm8jSGWiZLTw.text: My wife and I read the reviews and decided to give it a try.  Like most Americans,  we didn't even think of reservations on a Saturday night- our bad.  The staff went above and beyond the call of duty and got us a table.  The menu is more than adequate without being too much.  The food was the best,  most  authentic Italian that I have had outside of Italy.  All that with exceptional service.  Stay for dessert too, it is worth it. The only problem I found, is that it is a nine hour plane ride to come back again.

RifdEpyB1GMQ8IkKmncWYw.text: Went to this place last night on a rainy day in London with two of my best pals, after finding it on Yelp yesterday. It had good reviews and it lived up to the purpose. The starters were absolutely delicious- my friends had bruschetta and the other had a pate. I had an endive and blue cheese salad. Mains- we went for pasta- both the other girls had prawn spaghetti, I had the aubergine ravioli. The prawn option was really tasty, the ravioli was a little bland but in all fairness I think I could have (and should have) chosen something else on the menu- there was so much good stuff on there like salt cod, lemon sole etc.... which looked lovely when they came out to other tables.4 stars for location- tick, great starters- tick, a really tasty pudding shared- tick and one  extra for good luck. I liked this place and would go back.

h3ZM_0eX1jwlOZvhkMeYuw.text: The Pasta and salmon were great. The filet was okay, not much flavor. All of the salads were fresh and tasty.The waitstaff were very accommodating and friendly.
